title: Standing waves - plastic pipe partially in water

content.question:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A plastic pipe, open at both its top and bottom ends, is almost completely submerged in water, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. A tuning fork is struck, emitting sinusoidal sound waves, and is held above the pipe. The pipe is then slowly raised vertically out of the water, and the tuning fork is also raised such that the distance between the tuning fork and top of the pipe remains approximately the same, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. When the length of pipe above the water surface reaches a certain value <math alttext="l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>ℓ</mo></math>, sound from the tuning fork resonates in the pipe.

The procedure described previously is carried out using two different tuning forks, first with Tuning Fork <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> of frequency <math alttext="f sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and then with Tuning Fork <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> of frequency <math alttext="f sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, where <math alttext="f sub 2 is greater than f sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>. The pipe lengths above the water surface where resonance first occurs for tuning forks <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> are <math alttext="l sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mo>ℓ</mo><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="l sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mo>ℓ</mo><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, respectively.
(a) Indicate whether <math alttext="l sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mo>ℓ</mo><mn>2</mn></msub></math> is greater than, less than, or equal to <math alttext="l sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mo>ℓ</mo><mn>1</mn></msub></math>.

_____<math alttext="l sub 2 is greater than l sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mspace width="0.4em"></mspace><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mo>ℓ</mo><mn>2</mn></msub></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>></mo></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mo>ℓ</mo><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace></mstyle></math>_____<math alttext="l sub 2 is less than l sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><msub><mo>ℓ</mo><mn>2</mn></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mo>ℓ</mo><mn>1</mn></msub><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.4em"></mspace><mspace width="0.4em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace></math>_____<math alttext="l sub 2 equals l sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mspace width="0.4em"></mspace><msub><mo>ℓ</mo><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mo>ℓ</mo><mn>1</mn></msub></math>

Justify your selection without deriving or manipulating equations.

frqParts.text:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A plastic pipe, open at both its top and bottom ends, is almost completely submerged in water, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. A tuning fork is struck, emitting sinusoidal sound waves, and is held above the pipe. The pipe is then slowly raised vertically out of the water, and the tuning fork is also raised such that the distance between the tuning fork and top of the pipe remains approximately the same, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. When the length of pipe above the water surface reaches a certain value <math alttext="l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>ℓ</mo></math>, sound from the tuning fork resonates in the pipe.

The procedure described previously is carried out using two different tuning forks, first with Tuning Fork <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> of frequency <math alttext="f sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and then with Tuning Fork <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> of frequency <math alttext="f sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, where <math alttext="f sub 2 is greater than f sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>. The pipe lengths above the water surface where resonance first occurs for tuning forks <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> are <math alttext="l sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mo>ℓ</mo><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="l sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mo>ℓ</mo><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, respectively.
(a) Indicate whether <math alttext="l sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mo>ℓ</mo><mn>2</mn></msub></math> is greater than, less than, or equal to <math alttext="l sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mo>ℓ</mo><mn>1</mn></msub></math>.

_____<math alttext="l sub 2 is greater than l sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mspace width="0.4em"></mspace><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mo>ℓ</mo><mn>2</mn></msub></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>></mo></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mo>ℓ</mo><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace></mstyle></math>_____<math alttext="l sub 2 is less than l sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><msub><mo>ℓ</mo><mn>2</mn></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mo>ℓ</mo><mn>1</mn></msub><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.4em"></mspace><mspace width="0.4em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace></math>_____<math alttext="l sub 2 equals l sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mspace width="0.4em"></mspace><msub><mo>ℓ</mo><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mo>ℓ</mo><mn>1</mn></msub></math>

Justify your selection without deriving or manipulating equations.

Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> shows a point inside the pipe located a distance <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math> from the top of the pipe. When the sound from a tuning fork of frequency <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi></math> is resonating in the pipe, the air pressure <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>P</mi></math> at the point varies as a function of time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> according to the equation <math alttext="P equals, P sub 0, end sub, plus A, times, the sine of, open parenthesis, 2 pi f t, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>P</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>+</mo><mi>A</mi><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>sin</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>, where <math alttext="P sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> is the outside air pressure and <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>A</mi></math>, the pressure amplitude of the air in the pipe, is a function of <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math>. Let <math alttext="A sub max" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>A</mi><mi>max</mi></msub></math> be the amplitude at the location where the amplitude is a maximum
(b) Derive an equation for <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>A</mi></math>. Express <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>A</mi></math> in terms of <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math>, <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi></math>, <math alttext="A sub max" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>A</mi><mi>max</mi></msub></math>, the speed <math alttext="v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math> of sound in air, and physical constants, as appropriate.

The pipe remains at the same position where the tuning fork from part (b) creates a resonance in the pipe. The same tuning fork is struck a second time, this time resulting in a maximum pressure amplitude of <math alttext="2 A sub max" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>A</mi><mi>max</mi></msub></math> in the pipe.
(c) Indicate whether the new pressure amplitude at the top end of the pipe is greater than, less than, or the same as it was originally. Justify your answer using the equation you derived in part (b).

topic.text: 14.1: Properties of Wave Pulses and Waves

skill.text: 2.A: Derive a symbolic expression from known quantities by selecting and following a logical mathematical pathway.
